replies.body: I like the Garen icon way better than the Darius icon but I already know that more people are going to chose Darius D:

Can we get a response from Riot about this? Is there really going to be no way to attain the Garen/Eternal Reign icon if Darius wins (which he most likely will, seeing as he’s the more popular one of the two)?
No, the post has a table that shows you only get the icon of the champion who wins (AKA the side with the most completed missions).
Valor is actually correct. You might want to re-read it.

That table show that no matter what you will get an icon based on the one you choose the bonus for your faction winning is 1000 BE. Though you will only be able to get 1 of the 2 icons for free you are guaranteed to get one.
Look at it again. You can only earn the icon of the champion who wins, regardless of which you side with at the beginning of the event.
Incorrect, the context of the sentence states that the 1,000BE is the reward for being on the winning side.
Wrong, if you look at the table for Victory Scenario you will see that to the right of: "You chose God-King Garen and he lost" the reward is "Endless War Icon" and not the "Eternal Reign Icon".

Valor is correct. While it is true you will get an icon regardless of your team, it will always be that of the winning side (i.e. you choose Darius. If you win you get the Darius icon + 1000 BE, but if you lose you get the Garen icon). If you think otherwise reread the rewards table, and note which icon is rewarded in each scenario.

Good and evil is based on perspective. In this case, Garen is the guy who's in control, therefore he is the light, the so called good. Darius on the other hand is the rebel, one who usurps, therefore making him the dark, the so called evil, just because he wishes for change. If you think about it, the 'evil' in both years are technically the good ones or ones breaking free and ushering in change from what is the accepted norm of the so called 'good/light'

The idea here is that neither of them are particularly good. Both offer something, but demand something more precious in return. In Garen's case he offers security at the expense of liberty and Darius offers liberty at the expense of security. The reason, though, that neither side is meant to be a moral good is because the thing they take isn't worth what's offered in either case. In Darius's case you'll likely have a very short life and a very violent end, but in Garen's case you'll lose everything that makes you human.
